facts.text: This is an appeal under Section 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal under S. 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

facts.text: The appeal is directed against the order dated 15-4-1988 of the Customs Excise and Gold Control Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is directed against the order dated 15-4-1988 of the Customs Excise and Gold Control Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi.

facts.text: The appellant is the manufacturer of Hacksaw blades and Bandsaw Blades falling under Tariff Item No. 51-A iv of the Central Excise Tariff.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the manufacturer of Hacksaw blades and Bandsaw Blades falling under Tariff Item No. 51-A iv  of the Central Excise Tariff.

facts.text: The appellant filed a classification list as per Rule 173B of the Central Excise Rules 1944 on 26-3-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a classification list as per Rule 173B of the Central Excise Rules 1944 on 26-3-1985 in respect of their products furnishing the tariff rate of 15 ad valorem by mistake

facts.text: The classification list furnished tariff rate of 15 ad valorem by mistake instead of effective rates per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985.

anchor.surface_text: furnishing the tariff rate of 15 ad valorem by mistake instead of furnishing the effective rates of duty as per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985.

facts.text: Aggregate value of clearances in preceding year 1984-85 did not exceed Rs. 75 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The aggregate value of the clearance in the preceding year i.e. 1984-85 did number exceed Rs. 75 lakhs.

facts.text: For first clearance up to Rs. 7.5 lakhs, effective rate of duty is nil; next Rs. 7.5 lakhs, 3.75 ad valorem.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of first clearance up to an aggregate value number exceeding Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the effective rates of duty is nil and in the case of next clearance of Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the duty is 3.75 ad valorem.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Central Excise, Hyderabad approved the tariff rate of 15 ad valorem on 3-6-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise, Hyderabad, approved the tariff rate 15 ad valorem on 3-6-1985 instead of the above effective rates as the appellant did number claim the exemption

facts.text: Appellant filed revised classification list with effective rates retrospective from 26-3-1985 on 31-10-1985, which was approved.

anchor.surface_text: A revised classification list with the effective rates in respect of the products with retrospective effect from 26-3-1985 was filed on 31-10-1985. The revised classification list was approved.

facts.text: Appellant claimed excess payment of Rs. 2,55,172.55 as excise duty from 1-4-1985 to 31-8-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that they had paid excess Rs. 2,55,172.55 from 1-4-1985 to 31-8-1985 as excise duty.

facts.text: Appellant made refund application under Section 11B on 30-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: They made an application for refund as per rule under S. 11B of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 on 30-10-1985.

facts.text: Assistant Collector sanctioned refund claim only partly by order dated 13-12-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise by his order dated 13-12-1985 sanctioned the refund claim only partly.

facts.text: Refund for 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985 rejected as time-barred by Assistant Collector.

anchor.surface_text: For the period from 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985, the refund claim was rejected on the ground that the same was time barred.

facts.text: Assistant Collector held relevant date for limitation under S.11B is date of payment of duty by adjustment in personal ledger account.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector held that the refund claim for the period 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985 was time barred for the reason that under S. 11B, the relevant date for preferring the claim for a case such as that of the appellant was the date of payment of duty and, according to him, the duty had been paid by adjustment in the personal ledger account as and when goods were removed.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded that relevant date is date of assessment of RT-12 Returns filed monthly.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the appellant is that mere detailing in the personal ledger account should number be taken as the starting point for limitation and the relevant date should be the date on which RT-12 Returns which are filed on a monthly basis are assessed.

facts.text: Order of Assistant Collector confirmed by Collector of Central Excise Appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Assistant Collector was companyfirmed in the appeal by the Collector of Central Excise  Appeals .

facts.text: Appeal to Tribunal was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The further appeal to the Tribunal was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: RT-12 Return for April 1985 filed on 8-5-1985 and assessed on 29-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the RT-12 Return for the month of April, 1985 was filed on 8-5-1985 and the same was assessed on 29-10-1985.

facts.text: Classification list filed on 26-3-1985 was approved on 3-6-1985.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the classification list filed by the appellant for the period 1-4-85 to 27-4-85 was number approved till 3-6-85.

facts.text: Appellant cleared goods between 1-4-1985 and 3-6-1985 by debiting personal ledger account before approval.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee was clearing the goods by determining the duty himself and debiting the amount of duty in his personal ledger account. The amount of duty paid by him was obviously provisional

facts.text: Court held clearances between 1 April 1985 and 3 June 1985 were provisional assessment under procedure akin to R.9B.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the clearance of goods made by the appellant between 1st April and 3rd of June, 1985 were in accordance with the procedure for provisional assessment.

facts.text: Relevant date under S.11B clause (e) is date of adjustment after final assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In such a situation cl.  e  of para  B  of the Explanation under S. 11B will be attracted.

facts.text: Refund application filed on 30-10-1985 is within 6 months from assessment on 29-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, only from the date of this assessment that time bar in S. 11B will operate. In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, appellant entitled to full refund, no limitation bar.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the appeal. The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is numberbar of limitation as found by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Appellant paid duty by debit in personal ledger account, which is effective payment.

anchor.surface_text: Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is number a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.
S. 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

holdings.text: Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is not a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.

anchor.surface_text: Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is number a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debit in personal ledger account under R.173G constitutes effective payment as it reduces the assessee's deposit balance, rejecting claim that assessment date equals payment date under cl.(f).

holdings.text: The clearance of goods made by the appellant between 1st April and 3rd of June, 1985 were in accordance with the procedure for provisional assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the clearance of goods made by the appellant between 1st April and 3rd of June, 1985 were in accordance with the procedure for provisional assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending approval of classification list under R.173B, clearances by self-debit in PLA akin to R.9B provisional assessment procedure under self-removal scheme (Rules 173B, 173C, 173CC, 173F, 173G), no bond needed due to account balance.

holdings.text: In such a situation cl. e of para B of the Explanation under S. 11B will be attracted.

anchor.surface_text: In such a situation cl. e of para B of the Explanation under S. 11B will be attracted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisional nature of duty payment triggers cl.(e) of Explanation B to S.11B, making relevant date the adjustment after final assessment rather than payment date under cl.(f).

holdings.text: It is, therefore, only from the date of this assessment that time bar in S. 11B will operate. In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, only from the date of this assessment that time bar in S. 11B will operate. In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: RT-12 return for April 1985 assessed on 29-10-1985; refund filed next day on 30-10-1985 falls within 6-month limitation from relevant date under cl.(e).

holdings.text: We, therefore, allow the appeal holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is no bar of limitation as found by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the appeal. The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is numberbar of limitation as found by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of cl.(e) S.11B to facts removes limitation bar, entitling appellant to full refund of excess duty paid.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, accept this contention of the appellant. The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is numberbar of limitation as found by the Tribunal. We, therefore, allow the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; appellant entitled to full refund of Rs. 2,55,172.55 as the claim is not time barred under S. 11B
